{{Infobox organization | name = World Health Academy |image = World Health Academy Logo.jpg |size = |alt = |caption = |abbreviation = WHA |motto = |formation = {{Start date and age|2011|02|01}} |type = [[International nongovernmental organization|INGO]] |status = Association |professional_title = |headquarters = |location = [[Florence]], Italy |region_served = Worldwide |membership = |language = English |key_people = [[Robert A. Schwartz]]
[[Torello Lotti]] |main_organ = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = {{URL|worldhealth.academy}} }} [[File:Kurt Wüthrich receives World Health Academy Gold Medal.jpg|thumb|[[Kurt Wüthrich]] receives World Health Academy Gold Medal during the [[awards ceremony]] at the WHA's 1st International Winter Consensus Conference in [[Kitzbühel]], [[Austria]]]] The '''World Health Academy''' ('''WHA''') is an [[international non-governmental organization]] specializing in [[global health]]. It serves as a representative body for physicians worldwide, developing health policy, advancing continuing education programs, and speaking as a unified voice for medicine in international advocacy. The WHA is headquartered in [[Florence]], [[Italy]] and led by [[Robert A. Schwartz]], of [[Rutgers University]]. The WHA seeks to achieve optimal health for all people across borders, uniting the medical field to harness the collective expertise and power of its members. As the medical profession’s global and authoritative voice, the WHA assists governments and national medical associations in jointly tackling health problems and improving the welfare of their citizens. The ''International Journal of Medicine'' is an [[open access]] [[peer-reviewed]] [[scientific journal]] published by the World Health Academy. It covers primary research and [[secondary research]] from any discipline within [[medicine]]. The ''IJM'' Editorial Board consist of [[Nobel Prize]] laureates, [[Lasker Award]] recipients, and other prominent persons. ''Dermatologic Therapy'', a [[peer-reviewed]] [[scientific journal]] published by [[Wiley-Blackwell]], is also an official journal of the WHA.{{cite journal|title=Issue Information|journal=Dermatologic Therapy|volume=27|issue=1|year=2014|pages=ii–ii|issn=1396-0296|doi=10.1111/dth.12088|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/store/10.1111/dth.12088/asset/dth12088.pdf?v=1&t=hv74kq2h&s=e2c60adc6b095f1acb61af3f19191f7d5f00ce43}} ==Notable members, fellows, and staff== * [[Robert A. Schwartz]] * [[Torello Lotti]] * [[Andrew V. Schally]] * [[Ruth Arnon]] * Gideon Panter * [[Ravinder Maini]] * [[Bert Vogelstein]] * Michael Fox * [[Joseph G. Gall]] * Elmer David * [[John Bosley Ziegler|John Ziegler]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{Cite journal | last1 = Schwartz | first1 = RA. | title = World Health Academy 1st International Winter Consensus Conference of Dermatology, Kitzbühel, Austria, December 13-15, 2012. | journal = Int J Dermatol | volume = 52 | issue = 4 | pages = 519–20 |date=Apr 2013 | doi = 10.1111/ijd.12177 | PMID = 23489091 }} ==External links== * [http://worldhealth.academy Official website] [[Category:Global health]] [[Category:International medical and health organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2011]]

page.title: World Health Imaging, Telemedicine, and Informatics Alliance

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = World Health Imaging, Telemedicine and Informatics Alliance | logo = Whialogo.JPG | logo_size = 200px | type = [[501(c)#501(c)(3)|501(c)(3)]] [[Non-profit Organization]] | founded_date = [[Chicago, IL]], US | location = [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]], [[Illinois]]
[[United States]] | founder = Mike Hoaglin, Dave Kelso, Matt Glucksberg, Michael Diamond | key_people = [[Newton N. Minow]], Chair of the Board
Michael W. Ferro, Jr., Vice Chair{{cite web | accessdate = 2009-07-02 | url = http://www.worldhealthimaging.org/board.html | title = Board of Directors}}
Ivy Walker, CEO
{{cite web | accessdate = 2009-07-02 | url = http://www.worldhealthimaging.org/personnel.html | title = Personnel}} | area_served = Worldwide | focus = [[Cost effective|Low-cost]] [[medical imaging]], [[X-ray]], [[Health information technology|Health Information technology]], [[sustainability]] | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = One digital image can save a life | homepage = [http://www.worldhealthimaging.org worldhealthimaging.org] | dissolved = | footnotes = }} The '''World Health Imaging, Telemedicine and Informatics Alliance''' (WHITIA) is a non-profit [[global health]] technology and [[social venture]] established in 2006 by affiliates of [[Northwestern University]] near [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]].{{cite web | accessdate = 2009-07-02 | url = http://magazine.mccormick.northwestern.edu/FA2007/Xray.html | title = McCormick students and faculty tackle health care challenge in the developing world | publisher= Robert R. McCormick School of Engineering and Applied Science, Northwestern University}}{{cite web | url=http://www.mccormick.northwestern.edu/news/articles/494 | title = World Health Imaging Alliance Partners For X-Rays in Developing World | publisher = McCormick School of Engineering | accessdate = 2009-07-04}} WHITIA cultivates high-level strategic relationships with [[non-governmental organizations]], [[medical imaging|imaging]] industry innovators and [[academic]] institutions in order to integrate and deliver meaningful, sustainable, [[diagnostic]] technology to underserved communities worldwide. WHITIA's vision is to facilitate the deployment of thousands of digital medical imaging systems worldwide, providing one billion people with access to diagnostic imaging.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldhealthimaging.org/ |title=Welcome to WHITIA | Homepage |publisher=Worldhealthimaging.org |date= |accessdate=2012-04-15}} WHITIA was formerly known as the World Health Imaging Alliance (WHIA) until it formally expanded its scope in June 2009. WHITIA's first formal public launch was in April 2009 at the [[HIMSS|Healthcare Information and Management Systems Society (HIMSS)]] Annual Conference & Exhibition in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]]. WHITIA announced strategic partners including [[SEDECAL]], [[Carestream Health]] and [[Merge Healthcare]], receiving extensive coverage in [[Health IT]] magazines and publications.{{cite news | accessdate = 2009-07-02 | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS111037+06-Apr-2009+BW20090406 | title = Not-for-Profit Has a Vision to Help a Billion People | publisher= Reuters | date=2009-04-06}}{{cite web | accessdate = 2009-07-02 | url = https://finance.yahoo.com/news/Merge-Healthcare-Commits-1-bw-14855801.html?x=1&.v=1 | title = World Health Imaging Alliance Poised to Bring Imaging Diagnostics and Data to the Developing World | publisher= Yahoo Finance}} At the 2009 Annual Conference of the Society for Imaging Informatics in Medicine (SIIM) in [[Charlotte]], [[North Carolina]], WHITIA announced its partnership with [[Society for Imaging Informatics in Medicine|SIIM]], which will allow both organizations to collaborate on specific initiatives.{{cite web | accessdate = 2009-07-02 | url = http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20090605005136/en | title = World Health Imaging Alliance (WHIA) Announces Support From The Society for Imaging Informatics in Medicine (SIIM) | publisher= Business Wire}}{{cite web | accessdate = 2009-07-02 | url = http://www.imagingeconomics.com/news/2009-06-17_01.asp | title = World Health Imaging Alliance poised to bring imaging diagnostics and data to the developing world | publisher= Imaging Economics}} WHITIA was recently ranked #15 of the top 25 most influential people, institutions, and organizations in the radiology industry.{{cite web | accessdate = 2009-10-22 | url = http://www.rt-image.com/25_Most_Influential_in_Radiology_Recognizing_the_movers_and_shakers_in_the_radio/content=9004J05E48B6A084409698724488B0441 | title = 25 Most Influential in Radiology | publisher= rt Image}} At the 2009 [[Radiological Society of North America|RSNA]] Annual Meeting, WHITIA launched, '''Remi-d''', a remote-operated screening X-ray system for use in the developing world. Its strengths in these areas stem from the higher burden of [[Human Immunodeficiency Virus]] (HIV) and [[Tuberculosis]] (TB) co-infection, high incidences of [[Coalworker's pneumoconiosis|Black Lung disease]], or outbreaks of other infectious [[respiratory diseases]]. The teleradiology and remote-controlled features of Remi-d allow resource-limited areas such as sub-Saharan Africa, South and Central America and Southeast Asia, where [[Radiologist]]s and [[Radiographer]]s are in short supply to have a functioning X-ray service.{{cite web | accessdate = 2009-12-01 | url = http://www.news-medical.net/news/20091130/WHITIA-launches-digital-medical-X-ray-device-for-screening-infectious-diseases-in-developing-countries.aspx | title = WHITIA launches digital medical X-ray device for screening infectious diseases in developing countries | publisher= THE MEDICAL NEWS}} WHITIA currently has [[Pilot (experiment)|pilot]] [[System integration|integrated]] [[digital X-ray]] sites in [[South Africa]] and [[Guatemala]] at established [[clinics]] in need and is expanding to new qualified sites in [[partnership]] with [[NGOs]] such as [[Rotary International]] while cooperating with the [[local government|local]] and [[Central government|national governments]].{{cite web | accessdate = 2009-07-02 | url = http://www.healthtechwire.com/The-Industry-s-News-unb.146+M5a262949a06.0.html | title = SIIM to Support World Health Imaging Alliance | publisher= HealthTech Wire}} == Guatemala clinics == The Guatemala pilot sites in urban [[Guatemala City]] and [[rural]] [[Río Hondo, Zacapa|Río Hondo]] provide essential healthcare technology to thousands of people in the communities served. They are designed to be models for the wider expansion of the WHITIA network throughout the clinics in need in urban and rural Guatemala. The system's specific design for Guatemala City is an integration of some of WHITIA's partners' strengths and generosity: * [[SEDECAL]] provides the X-ray generator and controls * [[Carestream Health]] donates the [[Photostimulated luminescence|computed radiography]] (CR) digital scanner and plates * [[Kane X-ray]] donates personnel to perform installation and set up of the CR and [[Picture archiving and communication system|PACS]] This project was largely funded by several US and Guatemalan [[Rotary International|Rotary clubs]] along with the key resource support of the Guatemalan municipal and national governments.{{cite web | accessdate = 2011-01-09 | url = http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20110104006502/en/WHITIA-Announces-Completion-Digital-X-ray-Pilot-Sites | title = WHITIA Announces the Completion of Digital X-ray Pilot Sites in Urban and Rural Guatemala | publisher= Business Wire}} == References == == External links == *[http://www.worldhealthimaging.org/ Official webpage] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sv0q0hD-flM Video interview with WHITIA staff and overview of mission. Shown at Rotary International Convention 2008] {{DEFAULTSORT:World Health Imaging, Telemedicine, And Informatics Alliance}} [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Chicago]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Illinois]] [[Category:Global health]] [[Category:Health informatics and eHealth associations]]

revision.comment: fixed vandalism
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} [[File:World Heritage Logo global.svg|thumb|[[Logo]] of the [[UNESCO|United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization]] (UNESCO) [[World Heritage Committee]]]] A '''World Heritage site''' is a landmark or area which is selected by the [[United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization]] ([[UNESCO]]) as having cultural,Ann Marie Sullivan, Cultural Heritage & New Media: A Future for the Past, 15 J. Marshall Rev. Intell. Prop. L. 604 (2016) https://repository.jmls.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1392&context=ripl historical, scientific or other form of significance, and is legally protected by international treaties. The sites are judged important to the collective interests of humanity. To be selected, a World Heritage site must be an already classified landmark, unique in some respect as a geographically and historically identifiable place having special cultural or physical significance (such as an ancient ruin or historical structure, building, city, complex, desert, forest, island, lake, monument, mountain, or [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/cobi.12976/full wilderness area]). It may signify a remarkable accomplishment of humanity, and serve as evidence of our intellectual history on the planet.{{cite web|last1=Centre|first1=UNESCO World Heritage|title=The Criteria for Selection|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria/|website=whc.unesco.org|accessdate=1 February 2018|language=en}} The sites are intended for practical conservation for posterity, which otherwise would be subject to risk from human or animal trespassing, unmonitored/uncontrolled/unrestricted access, or threat from local administrative negligence. Sites are demarcated by UNESCO as protected zones.{{cite web|title=World Heritage|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/about/|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090630023048/http://whc.unesco.org/en/about/|archivedate=30 June 2009|df=dmy-all}} [[Lists of World Heritage Sites|The list]] is maintained by the international World Heritage Program administered by the UNESCO [[World Heritage Committee]], composed of 21 states parties which are elected by their General Assembly.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/comittee/|title=The World Heritage Committee|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Site|accessdate=14 October 2006|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061109181158/http://whc.unesco.org/en/comittee/|archivedate=9 November 2006|df=dmy-all}} The programme catalogues, names, and conserves sites of outstanding [[cultural heritage|cultural]] or [[natural heritage|natural]] importance to the common culture and heritage of [[World population|humanity]]. Under certain conditions, listed sites can obtain funds from the World Heritage Fund. The program began with the ''Convention Concerning the Protection of the World's Cultural and Natural Heritage'',[http://whc.unesco.org/archive/convention-en.pdf Convention Concerning the Protection of World's Cultural and Natural Heritage] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100704214349/http://whc.unesco.org/archive/convention-en.pdf |date=4 July 2010 }} which was adopted by the General Conference of [[UNESCO]] on 16 November 1972. Since then, 193 state parties have ratified the convention, making it one of the most widely recognized international agreements and the world's most popular cultural program. As of July 2018, a total of 1,092 World Heritage sites (845 cultural, 209 natural, and 38 mixed properties) exist across [[Table of World Heritage Sites by country|167 countries]]. [[List of World Heritage Sites in Italy|Italy]], with 54 sites, has the most of any country, followed by [[List of World Heritage Sites in China|China]] (53), [[List of World Heritage Sites in Spain|Spain]] (47), [[List of World Heritage Sites in France|France]] (44), [[List of World Heritage Sites in Germany|Germany]] (44), [[List of World Heritage Sites in India|India]] (37), and [[List of World Heritage Sites in Mexico|Mexico]] (35).{{Cite web|url=https:/whc.unesco.org/en/list|title=UNESCO World Heritage Centre - World Heritage List|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2018-07-03}} ==History== {{See also|World Heritage Committee}} {{Infobox treaty | name = Convention concerning the Protection of the World's Cultural and Natural Heritage | long_name = | image = | image_width = | caption = | type = | date_drafted = | date_signed = 16 November 1972 | location_signed = Paris, France | date_sealed = | date_effective = 17 December 1975 | condition_effective = 20 ratifications | date_expiration = | signatories = | parties = | ratifiers = 193 (189 [[UN member states]] plus the [[Cook Islands]], the [[Holy See]], [[Niue]], and [[State of Palestine|Palestine]]) | depositor = Director-General of the [[United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization]] | language = | languages = Arabic, English, French, Russian, and Spanish | wikisource = }} In 1954, the government of [[Egypt]] decided to build the new [[Aswan Dam|Aswan High Dam]], whose resulting future reservoir would eventually [[Flood|inundate]] a large stretch of the [[Nile]] valley containing cultural treasures of [[ancient Egypt]] and ancient [[Nubia]]. In 1959, the governments of Egypt and [[Sudan]] requested UNESCO to assist their countries to protect and rescue the endangered monuments and sites. In 1960, the Director-General of UNESCO launched an appeal to the member states for an International Campaign to Save the Monuments of Nubia.[http://whc.unesco.org/en/activities/172/ Monuments of Nubia-International Campaign to Save the Monuments of Nubia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090429024818/http://whc.unesco.org/en/activities/172 |date=29 April 2009 }} World Heritage Convention, UNESCO This appeal resulted in the excavation and recording of hundreds of sites, the recovery of thousands of objects, as well as the salvage and relocation to higher ground of a number of important temples, the most famous of which are the temple complexes of [[Abu Simbel temples|Abu Simbel]] and [[Philae]]. The campaign, which ended in 1980, was considered a success. As tokens of its gratitude to countries which especially contributed to the campaign's success, Egypt donated four temples: the [[Temple of Dendur]] was moved to the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in New York City, the [[Temple of Debod]] was moved to the [[Parque del Oeste]] in Madrid, the [[Temple of Taffeh]] was moved to the [[Rijksmuseum van Oudheden]] in the Netherlands, and the [[Temple of Ellesyia]] to [[Museo Egizio]] in Turin.[http://whc.unesco.org/en/activities/173/ The Rescue of Nubian Monuments and Sites] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150227222650/http://whc.unesco.org/en/activities/173/ |date=27 February 2015 }}, UNESCO The project cost $80 million, about $40 million of which was collected from 50 countries.{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} The project's success led to other safeguarding campaigns: saving [[Venice]] and its [[Venetian Lagoon|lagoon]] in Italy, the ruins of [[Mohenjo-daro]] in Pakistan, and the [[Borobodur]] Temple Compounds in Indonesia. UNESCO then initiated, with the [[International Council on Monuments and Sites]], a draft convention to protect the common cultural heritage of humanity. {{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} ===Convention and background=== The United States initiated the idea of cultural conservation with nature conservation. The [[White House]] conference in 1965 called for a "World Heritage Trust" to preserve "the world's superb natural and scenic areas and historic sites for the present and the future of the entire world citizenry". The [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]] developed similar proposals in 1968, and they were presented in 1972 to the [[United Nations Conference on the Human Environment]] in [[Stockholm]]. Under the World Heritage Committee, signatory countries are required to produce and submit periodic [[data reporting]] providing the World Heritage Committee with an overview of each participating nation's implementation of the World Heritage Convention and a "snapshot" of current conditions at World Heritage properties. A single text was agreed on by all parties, and the "Convention Concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage" was adopted by the General Conference of UNESCO on 16 November 1972. The Convention came into force on 17 December 1975. As of May 2017, it has been ratified by 193 states parties,{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/|author=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|title=States Parties – UNESCO World Heritage Centre|website=whc.unesco.org|accessdate=18 March 2018}} including 189 [[UN member states]] plus the [[Cook Islands]], the [[Holy See]], [[Niue]], and the [[State of Palestine]]. Only four UN member states have not ratified the Convention: Liechtenstein, Nauru, Somalia and Tuvalu.[http://www.unesco.org/eri/la/convention.asp?KO=13055&language=E Convention concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage: Treaty status] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130719235637/http://www.unesco.org/eri/la/convention.asp?KO=13055&language=E |date=19 July 2013 }}. ==Nominating process== A country must first list its significant cultural and natural sites; the result is called the Tentative List. A country may not nominate sites that have not been first included on the Tentative List. Next, it can place sites selected from that list into a Nomination File. The Nomination File is evaluated by the [[International Council on Monuments and Sites]] and the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature|World Conservation Union]]. These bodies then make their recommendations to the World Heritage Committee. The Committee meets once per year to determine whether or not to inscribe each nominated property on the World Heritage List and sometimes defers or refers the decision to request more information from the country which nominated the site. There are ten selection criteria – a site must meet at least one of them to be included on the list.{{cite web | url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/guidelines/ | title=The Operational Guidelines for the Implementation of the World Heritage Convention | publisher=UNESCO | accessdate=10 July 2017 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170714073431/http://whc.unesco.org/en/guidelines/ | archivedate=14 July 2017 | df=dmy-all }} ==Selection criteria== Up to 2004, there were six criteria for cultural heritage and four criteria for natural heritage. In 2005, this was modified so that there is now only one set of ten criteria. Nominated sites must be of "outstanding universal value" and meet at least one of the ten criteria.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria/|title=Criteria for Selection|publisher=World Heritage|accessdate=14 October 2006|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160612152223/http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria/|archivedate=12 June 2016|df=dmy-all}} These criteria have been modified or/amended several times since their creation. ===Cultural criteria=== [[File:Taj Mahal 2012.jpg|thumb|Site#252: [[Taj Mahal]], an example of a cultural heritage site.|alt=Site#252: The Taj Mahal, an example of a world heritage site.]]
  1. "represents a masterpiece of human creative genius and cultural significance"
  2. "exhibits an important interchange of human values, over a span of time, or within a cultural area of the world, on developments in architecture or technology, monumental arts, town-planning, or landscape design"
  3. "to bear a unique or at least exceptional testimony to a cultural tradition or to a civilization which is living or which has disappeared"
  4. "is an outstanding example of a type of building, architectural, or technological ensemble or landscape which illustrates a significant stage in human history"
  5. "is an outstanding example of a traditional human settlement, land-use, or sea-use which is representative of a culture, or human interaction with the environment especially when it has become vulnerable under the impact of irreversible change"
  6. "is directly or tangibly associated with events or living traditions, with ideas, or with beliefs, with artistic and literary works of outstanding universal significance"
    7. {{cite web|title=UNESCO World Heritage, The Criteria for Selection|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria/|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160612152223/http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria/|archivedate=12 June 2016|df=dmy-all}}
===Natural criteria=== [[File:Zerbras drinking.jpg|upright=1.15|thumb|Site#156: [[Serengeti National Park]], an example of a natural heritage site.]] [[File:80 - Machu Picchu - Juin 2009 - edit.2.jpg|upright=1.15|thumb|Site#274: [[Machu Picchu|Historic Sanctuary of Machu Picchu]], an example of a mixed heritage site.]]
  1. "contains superlative natural phenomena or areas of exceptional natural beauty and aesthetic importance"
  2. "is an outstanding example representing major stages of Earth's history, including the record of life, significant on-going geological processes in the development of landforms, or significant geomorphic or physiographic features"
  3. "is an outstanding example representing significant on-going ecological and biological processes in the evolution and development of terrestrial, fresh water, coastal and marine ecosystems, and communities of plants and animals"
  4. "contains the most important and significant natural habitats for in-situ conservation of biological diversity, including those containing threatened species of outstanding universal value from the point of view of science or conservation"
===Legal status of designated sites=== UNESCO designation as a World Heritage site provides ''[[prima facie]]'' evidence that such culturally sensitive sites are legally protected pursuant to the Law of War, under the [[Geneva Convention]], its articles, protocols and customs, together with other treaties including the [[Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict]] and international law. Thus, the Geneva Convention treaty promulgates: "Article 53. PROTECTION OF CULTURAL OBJECTS AND OF PLACES OF WORSHIP. Without prejudice to the provisions of the Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict of 14 May 1954,' and of other relevant international instruments, it is prohibited:{{cite web |author=UN General Assembly |authorlink=United Nations General Assembly |date=1979 |origyear=8 June 1977 |title=UN Treaty No. 17512 |series=Treaty Series |url=http://treaties.un.org/doc/Publication/UNTS/Volume%201125/volume-1125-I-17512-English.pdf |format=PDF |work='Volume 1125-1' UN |page=27 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309204240/http://treaties.un.org/doc/Publication/UNTS/Volume%201125/volume-1125-I-17512-English.pdf |archivedate=9 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}
:(a) To commit any acts of hostility directed against the historic monuments, works of art or places of worship which constitute the cultural or spiritual heritage of peoples; :(b) To use such objects in support of the military effort; :(c) To make such objects the object of reprisals." ==Extensions and other modifications== A country may request to extend or reduce the boundaries, modify the official name, or change the selection criteria of one of its already listed sites. Any proposal for a significant boundary change or modify the site's selection criteria must be submitted as if it were a new nomination, including first placing it on the Tentative List and then onto the Nomination File. A request for a minor boundary change, one that does not have a significantly impact on the extent of the property or affect its "outstanding universal value", is also evaluated by the advisory bodies before being sent to the Committee. Such proposals can be rejected by either the advisory bodies or the Committee if they judge it to be a significant change instead of a minor one. Proposals to change the site's official name is sent directly to the Committee. ==Endangered sites== {{main|List of World Heritage in Danger|Former UNESCO World Heritage sites}} A site may be added to the [[List of World Heritage in Danger]] if there are conditions that threaten the characteristics for which the landmark or area was inscribed on the World Heritage List. Such problems may involve armed conflict and war, natural disasters, pollution, poaching, or uncontrolled urbanization or human development. This danger list is intended to increase international awareness of the threats and to encourage counteractive measures. Threats to a site can be either proven imminent threats or potential dangers that could have adverse effects on a site.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/158/|title=List of World Heritage in Danger|publisher=UNESCO|accessdate=10 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150321040701/http://whc.unesco.org/en/158/|archivedate=21 March 2015|df=dmy-all}} The state of conservation for each site on the danger list is reviewed on a yearly basis, after which the committee may request additional measures, delete the property from the list if the threats have ceased or consider deletion from both the List of World Heritage in Danger and the World Heritage List. Only two sites have ever been [[Former UNESCO World Heritage sites|delisted]]: the [[Arabian Oryx Sanctuary]] in Oman and the [[Dresden Elbe Valley]] in Germany. The Arabian Oryx Sanctuary was directly delisted in 2007, instead of first being put on the danger list, after the Omani government decided to reduce the protected area's size by 90 percent.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/news/362|title=Oman's Arabian Oryx Sanctuary: first site ever to be deleted from UNESCO's World Heritage List|publisher=UNESCO|accessdate=10 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080118001455/http://whc.unesco.org/en/news/362|archivedate=18 January 2008|df=dmy-all}} The Dresden Elbe Valley was first placed on the danger list in 2006 when the World Heritage Committee decided that plans to construct the [[Waldschlösschen Bridge]] would significantly alter the valley's landscape. In response, the Dresden City Council attempted to stop the bridge's construction, but after several court decisions allowed the building of the bridge to proceed, the valley was removed from the World Heritage List in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/news/522|title=Dresden is deleted from UNESCO’s World Heritage List|publisher=UNESCO|accessdate=10 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170707003437/http://whc.unesco.org/en/news/522/|archivedate=7 July 2017|df=dmy-all}} The first global assessment to quantitatively measure [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0006320716310138 threats to Natural World Heritage sites] found that 63 percent of sites have been damaged by increasing [https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms12558 human pressures] including encroaching roads, agriculture infrastructure and settlements over the last two decades. These activities endanger Natural World Heritage sites and could compromise their unique values. Of the Natural World Heritage sites that contain forest, 91 percent of those experienced some loss since the year 2000. Many Natural World Heritage sites are more threatened than previously thought and require immediate conservation action. ==Statistics== [[File:Unesco_world_heritage_sites.png|upright=2.25|right|thumb|
UNESCO World Heritage sites {{nowrap|([[ShareMap:traveler/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Sites|interactive map]])}}
]] {{See also|World Heritage sites by country|Lists of World Heritage sites|List of World Heritage in Danger|List of World Heritage sites by year of inscription}} There are 1092 World Heritage sites located in 167 states. Of these, 845 are cultural, 209 are natural and 38 are mixed properties. The World Heritage Committee has divided the world into five geographic zones which it calls regions: Africa, Arab states, Asia and the Pacific, Europe and North America, and Latin America and the Caribbean. Russia and the [[Caucasus]] states are classified as European, while Mexico and the Caribbean are classified as belonging to the Latin America & Caribbean zone, despite their location in North America. The UNESCO geographic zones also give greater emphasis on administrative, rather than geographic associations. Hence, [[Gough Island]], located in the South Atlantic, is part of the Europe & North America region because the government of the United Kingdom nominated the site. The table below includes a breakdown of the sites according to these zones and their classification:{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/stat|title=World Heritage List Statistics|author=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514002820/http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/stat|archivedate=14 May 2011|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/pg.cfm?cid=31&l=en&&&&mode=table&order=region|title=UNESCO World Heritage Centre - World Heritage List|author=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|work=unesco.org|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027174218/http://whc.unesco.org/pg.cfm?cid=31&l=en&&&&mode=table&order=region|archivedate=27 October 2014|df=dmy-all}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 40%" ! style="width: 42%;" | Zone/region !! Cultural !! Natural !! Mixed !! Total !! % !! State Parties with inscribed properties |- align=center | align=left | '''[[List of World Heritage Sites in Africa|Africa]]''' || 52 || 38 || 5 || 95 || 8.70% || 35 |- align=center | align=left | '''[[List of World Heritage sites in the Arab states|Arab states]]''' || 76 || 5 || 3 || 84 || 7.69% || 18 |- align=center | align=left | '''[[List of World Heritage Sites#Asia|Asia]] and the [[List of World Heritage Sites in Oceania|Pacific]]''' || 181 || 65 || 12 || 258* || 23.63% || 36 |- align=center | align=left | '''[[List of World Heritage Sites#Europe|Europe]] and [[List of World Heritage Sites in North America|North America]]''' || 440 || 63 || 11 || 514* || 47.07% || 50 |- align=center | align=left | '''[[List of World Heritage Sites in the Americas|Latin America]] and the [[List of World Heritage Sites in the Caribbean|Caribbean]]''' || 96 || 38 || 7 || 141* || 12.91% || 28 |- align=center ! Total || 845 || 209 || 38 || 1092 || 100% || 167 |} *The properties "[[Uvs Nuur Basin]]" and "[[Transbaikal|Landscapes of Dauria]]" ([[Mongolia]], [[Russian Federation]]) are trans-regional properties located in Europe and Asia and the Pacific region. They are counted here in the Asia and the Pacific region. *The property "[[The Architectural Work of Le Corbusier|The Architectural Work of Le Corbusier, an Outstanding Contribution to the Modern Movement]]" ([[Argentina]], [[Belgium]], [[France]], [[Germany]], [[India]], [[Japan]], [[Switzerland]]) is a trans-regional property with component sites located in three regions - Europe and North America, Asia and the Pacific, and Latin America and the Caribbean. It is counted here in Europe and North America. ===Countries with fifteen or more sites=== Countries with fifteen or more World Heritage sites, as of July 2018.
ImageSize = width:602 height:auto barincrement:15 PlotArea = top:10 bottom:30 right:50 left:20 AlignBars = early DateFormat = yyyy Period = from:0 till:60 TimeAxis = orientation:horizontal ScaleMajor = unit:year increment:10 start:0 Colors = id:canvas value:rgb(1,1,1) id:black value:black id:red value:rgb(0.54,0.21,0) id:redl value:rgb(0.84,0.41,0) id:orange value:orange id:green value:green id:blue value:blue Backgroundcolors = canvas:canvas BarData = barset:Studentenbuden PlotData = width:5 align:left fontsize:S shift:(5,-4) anchor:till barset:Studentenbuden from: 0 till: 54 color:black text:"Italy" (54) from: 0 till: 53 color:black text:"China" (53) from: 0 till: 47 color:red text:"Spain" (47) from: 0 till: 43 color:red text:"France" (44) from: 0 till: 43 color:red text:"Germany" (44) from: 0 till: 37 color:redl text:"India" (37) from: 0 till: 34 color:redl text:"Mexico" (35) from: 0 till: 31 color:redl text:"United Kingdom" (31) from: 0 till: 28 color:orange text:"Russia" (28) from: 0 till: 23 color:orange text:"Iran" (23) from: 0 till: 23 color:orange text:"United States" (23) from: 0 till: 22 color:orange text:"Japan" (22) from: 0 till: 21 color:orange text:"Brazil" (21) from: 0 till: 19 color:green text:"Australia" (19) from: 0 till: 19 color:green text:"Canada" (19) from: 0 till: 18 color:green text:"Greece" (18) from: 0 till: 18 color:green text:"Turkey" (18) from: 0 till: 15 color:green text:"Poland" (15) from: 0 till: 15 color:green text:"Portugal" (15) from: 0 till: 15 color:green text:"Sweden" (15) barset:skip
==Consequences== Despite the successes of World Heritage listing in promoting conservation, the UNESCO administered project has attracted criticism from some for perceived under-representation of heritage sites outside Europe, disputed decisions on site selection and adverse impact of mass tourism on sites unable to manage rapid growth in visitor numbers.{{cite news|last1=Barron|first1=Laignee|title='Unesco-cide': does world heritage status do cities more harm than good?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2017/aug/30/unescocide-world-heritage-status-hurt-help-tourism|accessdate=3 September 2017|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=30 August 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Vallely|first1=Paul|title=The Big Question: What is a World Heritage Site, and does the accolade make a difference?|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/politics/the-big-question-what-is-a-world-heritage-site-and-does-the-accolade-make-a-difference-997955.html|work=The Independent|date=7 November 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027192333/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/politics/the-big-question-what-is-a-world-heritage-site-and-does-the-accolade-make-a-difference-997955.html|archivedate=27 October 2016|df=dmy-all}} A sizable [[Lobbying|lobbying industry]] has grown around the awards because World Heritage listing has the potential to significantly increase tourism revenue from sites selected. Site listing bids are often lengthy and costly, putting poorer countries at a disadvantage. Eritrea's efforts to promote [[Asmara]] are one example.{{cite news|title=Modernist masterpieces in unlikely Asmara|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/prospero/2016/07/architecture-eritrea?zid=317|work=The Economist|date=20 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170715102559/https://www.economist.com/blogs/prospero/2016/07/architecture-eritrea?zid=317|archivedate=15 July 2017|df=dmy-all}} In 2016, the Australian government was reported to have successfully lobbied for [[Great Barrier Reef]] conservation efforts to be removed from a UNESCO report titled 'World Heritage and Tourism in a Changing Climate'. The Australian government's actions were in response to their concern about the negative impact that an 'at risk' label could have on tourism revenue at a previously designated UNESCO World Heritage site.{{cite news|last1=Slezak|first1=Michael|title=Australia scrubbed from UN climate change report after government intervention|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/27/australia-scrubbed-from-un-climate-change-report-after-government-intervention|work=The Guardian|date=26 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027130133/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/27/australia-scrubbed-from-un-climate-change-report-after-government-intervention|archivedate=27 October 2016|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|last1=Hasham|first1=Nicole|title=Government spent at least $400,000 lobbying against Great Barrier Reef 'danger' listing|url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/government-spent-at-least-400000-lobbying-against-great-barrier-reef-danger-listing-20150914-gjlwr2.html|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=17 September 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161228235450/http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/government-spent-at-least-400000-lobbying-against-great-barrier-reef-danger-listing-20150914-gjlwr2.html|archivedate=28 December 2016|df=dmy-all}} A number of listed World Heritage locations such as [[George Town, Penang]], and [[Casco Viejo, Panama]], have struggled to strike the balance between the economic benefits of catering to greatly increased visitor numbers and preserving the original culture and local communities that drew the recognition.{{cite news|last1=Maurel|first1=Cholé|title=The unintended consequences of UNESCO world heritage listing|url=https://theconversation.com/the-unintended-consequences-of-unesco-world-heritage-listing-71047|accessdate=4 September 2017|publisher=The Conversation}} ==See also== * [[GoUNESCO]] * [[Index of conservation articles]] * [[UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists]] * [[Memory of the World Programme]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|World Heritage Sites}} {{Wikivoyage|UNESCO World Heritage List}} {{Library resources box |by=no |onlinebooks=yes |others=yes |about=yes |label=World Heritage Site |viaf= |lccn= |lcheading= |wikititle= }} * [http://whc.unesco.org UNESCO World Heritage portal] – Official website (in English and French) * [http://www.bunktravel.com/india-cultural-heritage-places/ Travel guide to UNESCO Sites] ** [http://whc.unesco.org/en/list The World Heritage List] – Official searchable list of all Inscribed Properties ** [http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/kml KML file of the World Heritage List] – Official [[Keyhole Markup Language|KML]] version of the list for [[Google Earth]] and [[NASA Worldwind]] ** [http://whc.unesco.org/en/soc UNESCO Information System on the State of Conservation of World Heritage properties] - Searchable online tool with over 3.400 reports on World Heritage sites ** [http://whc.unesco.org/en/forests Official overview of the World Heritage Forest Program] ** [http://whc.unesco.org/en/conventiontext Convention Concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage] – Official 1972 Convention Text in 7 languages *** [https://web.archive.org/web/20060207191942/http://law-ref.org/HERITAGE/index.html The 1972 Convention at Law-Ref.org] – Fully indexed and crosslinked with other documents * [http://protectedplanet.net Protected Planet] — View all natural world heritage sites in the World Database on Protected Areas * [http://ocean.si.edu/blog/world-heritage-goes-marine World Heritage Site – Smithsonian Ocean Portal] * [http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1636166,00.html ''Time'' magazine. The Oscars of the Environment – UNESCO World Heritage Site] * [http://www.unescochair.usi.ch/ UNESCO chair in ICT to develop and promote sustainable tourism in World Heritage Sites] {{Lists of World Heritage Sites}} {{Portal bar|United Nations|Environment|Culture}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:World Heritage Sites| ]] [[Category:1972 in the environment]] [[Category:1972 introductions]] [[Category:Global culture]] [[Category:Protected areas]] [[Category:UNESCO]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox book series | name = World Trade Report | image = World Trade Organization (logo and wordmark).svg | image_caption = Official logo of WTO | books = | author = [[World Trade Organization]] | editors = | title_orig = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[Switzerland]] | language = [[English language|English]] | discipline = <!-- or |genre= --> | publisher = | pub_date = | english_pub_date = | media_type = | number_of_books = | list_books = | oclc = | preceded by = | followed by = | website = https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/reser_e/wtr_e.htm }}
The '''World Trade Report''' (WTR) is the annual report published since 2003 by the [[World Trade Organization]]. Each WTR provides an in-depth analysis of an aspect of trends in [[international trade]], [[trade policy]] issues and the multilateral trading system.
==2016 Report== The [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/publications_e/wtr16_e.htm 2016 World Trade Report] examines the participation of [[Small and medium-sized enterprises]] (SMEs) in international trade, how the international trade landscape is changing for SMEs, and what the multilateral trading system does and can do to encourage more widespread and inclusive SME participation in [[global markets]].
==List of World Trade Reports==
*2017: [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/publications_e/wtr17_e.htm Trade, technology and jobs] *2016: [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/publications_e/wtr16_e.htm Levelling the trading field for SMEs] *2015: [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/publications_e/wtr15_e.htm Speeding up trade: benefits and challenges of implementing the WTO Trade Facilitation Agreement] *2014: [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/publications_e/wtr14_e.htm Trade and development: recent trends and the role of the WTO] *2013: [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/publications_e/wtr13_e.htm Factors shaping the future of world trade] *2012: [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/publications_e/wtr12_e.htm Trade and public policies: A closer look at non-tariff measures in the 21st century] *2011: [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/publications_e/wtr11_e.htm The WTO and preferential trade agreements: From co-existence to coherence] *2010: [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/publications_e/wtr10_e.htm Trade in Natural Resources] *2009: [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/publications_e/wtr09_e.htm Trade Policy Commitments and Contingency Measures] *2008: [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/publications_e/wtr08_e.htm Trade in a Globalizing World] *2007: [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/publications_e/wtr07_e.htm Six decades of multilateral trade cooperation: What have we learnt?] *2006: [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/publications_e/wtr06_e.htm Subsidies, trade and the WTO] *2005: [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/publications_e/wtr05_e.htm Trade, standards and the WTO] *2004: [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/publications_e/wtr04_e.htm Coherence] *2003: [https://www.wto.org/english/res_e/publications_e/wtr03_e.htm Trade and development]
==External links== * [http://www.wto.org/english/res_e/reser_e/wtr_e.htm World Trade Report]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Css Image Crop |Image = UN_DESA_continent_population_1950_to_2100.svg |bSize = 500 |cWidth = 275 |cHeight = 275 |oLeft = 23 |oTop = 225 |Location = right |Description = Estimated and projected populations of the world and its inhabited continents from 1950. The shaded regions correspond to range of projections by the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs; for example, it estimates that the world population will reach 8 billion between 2022 and 2035.[http://esa.un.org/wpp/unpp/panel_population.htm World Population Prospects, the 2010 Revision] }} '''World population milestones''' were unnoticed until the 20th century, since there were no reliable data on [[global population]] dynamics.Vaclav Smil, [http://www.ippnw.org/pdf/mgs/5-2-smil.pdf "Global Population: Milestones, Hopes, and Concerns"], ''Medicine & Global Survival'', October 1998; Vol. 5, No. 2, 105–108 It is estimated that the population of the world reached one billion for the first time in 1804. It would be another 123 years before it reached two billion in 1927, but it took only 33 years to rise by another billion people, reaching three billion in 1960. Thereafter, the global population reached four billion in 1974, five billion in 1987, six billion in 1999 and, by some estimates, seven billion in October 2011 with other estimates being in March 2012.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-15459643 |title=Population seven billion: UN sets out challenges|date=26 October 2011|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2011-10-27}} It is projected to reach eight billion by 2024–2030. According to current projections, the world's population is likely to reach around nine billion by 2035–2050, with alternative scenarios ranging from a low of 7.4 billion to a high of more than 10.6 billion. *{{Cite book |chapter=Ch. 5: Population Size and Composition|title=World Population Prospects, the 2000 Revision |volume=Vol.III |publisher=United Nations Population Division |page=171 |url=https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/wpp2000/chapter5.pdf |accessdate=3 July 2010 |postscript= }} *{{Cite book |year=2002 |chapter=Executive Summary |title=World Population Prospects: The 2002 Revision Volume III: Analytical Report |url=https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/wpp2002/English.pdf |accessdate=3 July 2010 |postscript=}} *{{Cite journal |year=2004 |pages=3, 14 |title=World Population to 2300 |place=New York |publisher=United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs: Population Division |url=https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/longrange2/WorldPop2300final.pdf |accessdate=3 July 2010 |postscript=}} *{{Cite journal |date=June 2010 |title=World Population: 1950–2050 |place= |publisher=[[United States Census Bureau|U.S. Census Bureau]], Population Division |url=https://www.census.gov/ipc/www/idb/worldpopgraph.php |accessdate=3 July 2010 |postscript=}} *{{Cite journal |year=2009 |title=2009 World Population Data Sheet |place=Washington, DC |publisher=[[Population Reference Bureau]] |url=http://www.prb.org/pdf09/09wpds_eng.pdf |accessdate=3 July 2010 |postscript=}} Projected figures vary depending on underlying statistical assumptions and which variables are manipulated in projection calculations, especially the [[fertility rate|fertility variable]]. Long-range predictions to 2150 range from a population decline to 3.2 billion in the 'low scenario', to 'high scenarios' of 24.8 billion. One scenario predicted a massive increase to 256 billion by 2150, assuming fertility remains at 1995 levels.{{Cite book |year=2003 |chapter=Key Findings |title=Long-Range Population Projections |work=Proceedings of the United Nations Technical Working Group on Long-Range Population Projections |place=New York |publisher=United Nations: Department of Economic and Social Affairs |url=https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/longrange/longrangeKeyFind.pdf |accessdate=3 July 2010 |postscript=}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; float:right; clear:right; margin-left:8px; margin-right:0;" ! colspan=10 style="text-align:center;" | World population milestones in billions |- ! Population ! 1 !! 2 !! | 3 !! 4 !! 5 !! 6 !! 7 !! ''8'' !! ''9'' |- ! Year | 1804 || 1927 || 1959 || 1974 || 1987 || 1999 || 2011 || ''2026'' || ''2042'' |- ! Years elapsed | –– || 123 || 32 || 15 || 13 || 12 ||12||''15''|| ''16'' |} ==Global billionth milestones== There is no estimation for the exact day or month the world's population surpassed each of the one and two billion marks. The days of three and four billion were not officially noted, but the International Database of the [[United States Census Bureau]] places them in July 1959 and April 1974.{{cn|date=September 2017}} ===Five billion=== '''The Day of Five Billion''', 11 July 1987, was designated by the [[United Nations Population Fund]] as the approximate day on which [[world population]] reached five billion. '''Matej Gašpar''' from [[Zagreb]], Croatia (then [[SR Croatia]], [[SFR Yugoslavia]]), was chosen as the symbolic 5-billionth person concurrently alive on [[Earth]]. The honor went to Zagreb because the [[1987 Summer Universiade]] was taking place in the city at the time.{{cite web|author=Ankica Barbir-Mladinović|title=Petomilijarditi "Zemljanin": Ne slušati stereotipe|url=http://www.slobodnaevropa.org/content/petomilijarditi_zemljanin_ne_slusati_stereotipe/24269206.html|date=19 July 2011|accessdate=1 October 2011|language=Croatian|publisher=[[Radio Free Europe]]}}{{cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE7DB123EF931A25754C0A961948260|title=And Baby Makes Five billion: U.N. Hails a Yugoslav Infant|work=New York Times|date=12 July 1987|accessdate=1 October 2011}} ===Six billion=== The [[United Nations Population Fund]] designated 12 October 1999 as the approximate day on which the [[world population]] reached six billion.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/aponline/19991012/aponline181217_000.htm |title=World Population Hits 6 billion| author=Edith M. Lederer| date=12 October 1999| accessdate=12 October 2010|work=The Washington Post}} It was officially designated '''The Day of Six Billion'''. Demographers do not universally accept this date as being exact. In fact there has been subsequent research which places the day of six billion nearer to 18 June or 19 June 1999.{{cite web|url=http://www.math.berkeley.edu/~galen/popclk.html |title=Population Clock}} The International Programs division of the United States Census Bureau estimated that the world population reached six billion on 21 April 1999.{{citation needed|date=November 2011}} United Nations Population Fund spokesman Omar Gharzeddine disputed the date of the Day of Six Billion by stating, "The U.N. marked the '6 billionth' [person] in 1999, and then a couple of years later the Population Division itself reassessed its calculations and said, actually, no, it was in 1998."{{cite web|author=Alan Boyle, Science Editor, NBC News |url=http://cosmiclog.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2011/10/28/8525681-7-billion-people-how-do-they-know |title=Cosmic Log – 7 billion people? How do they know? |publisher=Cosmiclog.msnbc.msn.com |date=2011-10-28 |accessdate=2013-10-31}} On the Day of Six Billion, [[UN Secretary-General]] [[Kofi Annan]] was in [[Sarajevo]], Bosnia and Herzegovina to monitor the [[Dayton Agreement]]. At midnight he went to Koševo Hospital, where '''Adnan Mević''', born at 12.01 am, was named the symbolic 6 billionth concurrently alive person on [[Earth]].{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/News/Press/docs/1999/19991014.sgt2204.doc.html|title=The Secretary-General, in two-day stopover in Sarajevo, confers with local leaders, United Nations Representative|date=12 October 1999|publisher=United Nations|pages=SG/T/2204|accessdate=2 May 2012}} He is the first son of Fatima Mević and Jasminko Mević and weighed 3.5 kg.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/472704.stm World UN chief welcomes six billionth baby] ===Seven billion=== {{main|Day of Seven Billion}} The "[[Day of Seven Billion]]" was targeted by the United States Census Bureau to be in March 2012,{{cite web |url=https://www.census.gov/population/popclockworld.html |title=U.S. Census Bureau – World POPClock Projection|accessdate=2011-10-27}} while the Population Division of the United Nations suggested 31 October 2011,[http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp/Other-Information/faq.htm World Population Prospects, the 2008 Revision Frequently Asked Questions] Population Division of the Department of Economic and Social Affairs of the United Nations Secretariat, updated 10 November 2010. Retrieved 26 January 2011. and the latter date was officially designated by the [[United Nations Population Fund]] (UNFPA) as the approximate day on which the [[world population|world's population]] reached seven billion people.[http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp/Other-Information/faq.htm World Population Prospects, the 2008 Revision Frequently Asked Questions] Population Division of the Department of Economic and Social Affairs of the United Nations Secretariat updated 10 November 2010. Retrieved 26 January 2011 United Nations Secretary General [[Ban Ki-moon]] spoke at the [[United Nations Headquarters|United Nations building]] in [[New York City]] on this milestone in the size of world population, and promoted the website 7 Billion Actions.{{cite web|url=https://www.unfpa.org/public/home/news/events/pid/8533|title=Day of 7 Billion|publisher=UNFPA|accessdate=16 October 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.7billionactions.org/about|title=About 7 Billion Actions|publisher=7 Billion Actions|accessdate=16 October 2011}} Ban Ki-moon did not choose a symbolic seven billionth baby, but several groups proposed candidates: Nargis Kumar of [[Uttar Pradesh]], [[India]],{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-15517259|title=India welcomes 'world's seven billionth baby'|date=31 October 2011|accessdate=31 October 2011|publisher=BBC News }} Danica May Camacho of [[Manila]], [[Philippines]]{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/oct/31/seven-billionth-baby-born-philippines?newsfeed=true|title=World's 'seven billionth baby' is born|date=2011-10-31|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|accessdate=2011-10-31|location=London|first=Jasmine|last=Coleman}} and Wattalage Muthumai of [[Colombo]], [[Sri Lanka]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/caption-story/14447-seven-billionth-child-born-in-sl.html |title=Seven billionth child born in SL | Caption Story |publisher=Dailymirror.lk |date=2011-10-31 |accessdate=2012-10-05}} ==National and regional population== {{See also|List of population milestones by country}} National or subnational governments have sometimes made similar designations based on the date estimated by a demographic agency. Some national milestones relate to [[citizen]]s rather than [[residency (domicile)|resident]]s. Commentators in countries with high [[immigration]] have pointed out that a population milestone may be reached by an immigrant rather than [[Rate of natural increase|natural increase]].{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-02-16/australias-population-reaches-24-million/7170274|title=Australia's population hits 24 million people, ABS clock shows|date=2016-02-16|work=[[ABC Online]] |quote=The ABS said it was unclear whether the 24 millionth Australian was a newborn or a migrant|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=6 April 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/newslocal/northern-beaches/baby-reed-is-one-in-23-million-almost/story-fngr8hax-1226627384262|title=Baby Reed is one in 23 million as Australia's population hits a milestone|work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]] |location= Sydney, Australia |quote=He said the 23rd millionth person could be a newborn but could equally be a person coming to work in Australia or a returning backpacker who had been away for more than a year.|accessdate=6 April 2016}} {{incomplete-list|date=April 2016}} {|class="wikitable sortable" |+ ! Country/nationality !! Population !! Born (date) !! Name and surname !! Notes !! Foot-
notes |- | [[Munich]] ||data-sort-value=1| 1m || {{date|1957-12-15}} || Thomas Seehaus || Awarded by [[List of mayors of Munich|Mayor]] [[Thomas Wimmer (politician)|Thomas Wimmer]] with a 1,000 [[Deutsche Mark|mark]] savings account. || {{cite news|url=http://www.tagesspiegel.de/zeitung/das-millionerl/1122802.html|title=Das Millionerl|work=[[Der Tagesspiegel]]|accessdate=14 June 2017|language=de}} |- | United States ||data-sort-value=200| 200m || {{date|1967-11-20}} || [[Robert Ken Woo Jr]] || Named by [[Life (magazine)|''Life'' magazine]], not the government.
